perturbation.original_text:
12. Indemnity and Liability
12.1 Each Party ("Indemnitor") will defend, indemnify and hold the other Party (including associated officers, directors, shareholders, employees, agents and affiliates) (cumulatively, "Indemnitee") harmless from and against any and all losses, damages, claims, liabilities and expenses (including reasonable legal fees), suffered or incurred as a result of or in connection with any claim, suit, action, demand, or proceeding brought against Indemnitee based upon (a) a claim of a failure to perform, or a breach by Indemnitor of, any obligation, warranty, representation or covenant in this Agreement; (b) a claim of personal injury or property damage arising out of the fault or negligence of Indemnitor, its representatives, agents, or employees; or (c) a claim of infringement or misappropriation of any patent, trademark, copyright or other proprietary right held by any third party.
perturbation.changed_text:
12. Indemnity and Liability
12.1 Each Party ("Indemnitor") will defend, indemnify and hold the other Party (including associated officers, directors, shareholders, employees, agents and affiliates) (cumulatively, "Indemnitee") harmless from and against any and all losses, damages, claims, liabilities and expenses (including reasonable legal fees), suffered or incurred as a result of or in connection with any claim, suit, action, demand, or proceeding brought against Indemnitee based upon (a) a claim of a failure to perform, or a breach by Indemnitor of, any obligation, warranty, representation or covenant in this Agreement; (b) a claim of personal injury or property damage arising out of the fault or negligence of Indemnitor, its representatives, agents, or employees.
perturbation.explanation: Removing clause (c), which covers claims of infringement or misappropriation of intellectual property rights, significantly limits the scope of the indemnity. This could leave the Indemnitee exposed to substantial liabilities if they face an IP-related claim due to the Indemnitor's actions. This omission creates a legal contradiction with standard business practices and expectations regarding IP protection, potentially violating implied warranties or creating unfair business practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Uniform Commercial Code § 2312 - Warranty of Title and Against Infringement; Buyer's Obligation Against Infringement
perturbation.law_explanation: California Uniform Commercial Code § 2312 implies a warranty against infringement unless explicitly excluded. By removing the specific indemnification for IP infringement, the contract may not sufficiently disclaim this implied warranty, especially regarding the use of trademarks and other intellectual property. This creates ambiguity and potential liability for the Indemnitee should a third-party IP claim arise related to the Sponsorship.
perturbation.scraped_snippet: California Code, COM 2312 skip to content home accessibility FAQ feedback sitemap login x Quick Search: Bill Number Bill Keyword Home Bill Information California Law Publications Other Resources My Subscriptions My Favorites California Law >> >> Code Section Code Section Code: Select Code CONS BPC CIV CCP COM CORP EDC ELEC EVID FAM FIN FGC FAC GOV HNC HSC INS LAB MVC PEN PROB PCC PRC PUC RTC SHC UIC VEH WAT WIC Article: Section: Code: Select Code All BPC CIV CCP COM CORP EDC ELEC EVID FAM FIN FGC FAC GOV HNC HSC INS LAB MVC PEN PROB PCC PRC PUC RTC SHC UIC VEH WAT WIC Section: Keyword(s): Code Search Text Search Up^ << Previous Next >> cross-reference chaptered bills PDF | Add To My Favorites Search Phrase: Code Text Commercial Code - COM DIVISION 2. SALES [2101 - 2801] ( Division 2 enacted by Stats. 1963, Ch. 819. ) CHAPTER 3. General Obligation and Construction of Contract [2301 - 2328] ( Chapter 3 enacted by Stats. 1963, Ch. 819. ) 2312. (1) Subject to subdivision (2) there is in a contract for sale a warranty by the seller that (a) The title conveyed shall be good, and its transfer rightful; and (b) The goods shall be delivered free from any security interest or other lien or encumbrance of which the buyer at the time of contracting has no knowledge. (2) A warranty under subdivision (1) will be excluded or modified only by specific language or by circumstances which give the buyer reason to know that the person selling does not claim title in himself or that he is purporting to sell only such right or title as he or a third person may have. (3) Unless otherwise agreed a seller who is a merchant regularly dealing in goods of the kind warrants that the goods shall be delivered free of the rightful claim of any third person by way of infringement or the like but a buyer who furnishes specifications to the seller must hold the seller harmless against any such claim which arises out of compliance with the specifications. (Enacted by Stats. 1963, Ch. 819.)
perturbation.justification: The original contract text includes an indemnification clause (12.1(c)) covering claims of infringement or misappropriation of intellectual property rights. The changed text omits this clause. The Law Explanation posits that this omission might not sufficiently disclaim the implied warranty against infringement under California Uniform Commercial Code § 2312. The Scraped Law Snippet, specifically COM 2312(3), states that 'unless otherwise agreed a seller who is a merchant regularly dealing in goods of the kind warrants that the goods shall be delivered free of the rightful claim of any third person by way of infringement or the like'. While the original contract provided specific indemnification, removing it creates ambiguity as to whether the warranty against infringement is effectively disclaimed. Although the contract doesn't explicitly contradict the law, the omission significantly weakens the Indemnitee's protection regarding IP claims, potentially leading to a situation where the implied warranty of non-infringement applies without clear contractual recourse. This creates a moderate contradiction because while not directly violating the law, it undermines protections that the law anticipates parties can agree to.

perturbation.original_text: 15.10 Governing Law and Jurisdiction. Without reference to choice or conflict of law principles, this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of California, USA. The Parties unconditionally submit to exclusive jurisdiction of and accept as the exclusive venue for any legal proceeding involving this Agreement the state and federal courts located in the County of Los Angeles, California. Before any Party (the "Complaining Party") may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the "Non Complaining Party"), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party's complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least thirty (30) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints. Any dispute, claim or controversy arising out of or relating to this Agreement or the breach, termination, enforcement, interpretation, or validity thereof, including the determination of the scope and applicability of this agreement to arbitrate, shall be determined by arbitration in Los Angeles County, California, by an arbitrator of JAMS, in accordance with its arbitration rules and procedures then in effect. Judgment on the arbitrator's award may be entered in any court having jurisdiction. The prevailing Party in any dispute involving this Agreement shall be entitled to recover from the other Party its costs, expenses, and reasonable attorneys' fees (including any fees for expert witnesses, paralegals, or other legal service providers). This Section 15.10 shall not preclude or place any condition on any Party from seeking injunctive relief from a court of appropriate jurisdiction.
perturbation.changed_text: 15.10 Governing Law and Jurisdiction. Without reference to choice or conflict of law principles, this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of California, USA. The Parties unconditionally submit to exclusive jurisdiction of and accept as the exclusive venue for any legal proceeding involving this Agreement the state and federal courts located in the County of Los Angeles, California. The prevailing Party in any dispute involving this Agreement shall be entitled to recover from the other Party its costs, expenses, and reasonable attorneys' fees (including any fees for expert witnesses, paralegals, or other legal service providers). This Section 15.10 shall not preclude or place any condition on any Party from seeking injunctive relief from a court of appropriate jurisdiction.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement for pre-litigation dispute resolution (good faith attempt to resolve disputes privately and subsequent discussion) directly contradicts the California Rules of Court regarding alternative dispute resolution. Many California courts require or strongly encourage parties to participate in mediation or other forms of ADR before proceeding to trial. Omitting this clause bypasses this process, potentially leading to unnecessary litigation costs and delays. Furthermore, removing the arbitration clause removes the requirement to arbitrate the dispute. This is a drastic measure and will impact the costs of any legal disputes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Rules of Court, Rule 3.216. Mandatory settlement conferences
perturbation.law_explanation: Rule 3.216 allows courts to order settlement conferences, but more fundamentally, it reflects a policy of encouraging alternative dispute resolution. The omitted text provided a contractual mechanism for ADR. Its removal pushes disputes directly into the court system, potentially violating the spirit and intent of the rule and increasing legal costs.
perturbation.justification: The original contract mandated pre-litigation dispute resolution efforts, including a good-faith attempt to resolve disputes privately and subsequent discussion, as well as mandatory arbitration. The changed contract removes these requirements. The LLM's law explanation suggests that this removal contradicts the spirit and intent of encouraging alternative dispute resolution, potentially violating California Rules of Court. While the scraped law snippet is missing, the Perturbation Explanation highlights that many California courts encourage or require ADR before trial. The omission of the ADR clauses in the changed contract increases the likelihood of direct litigation, which undermines the general legal preference and potential court requirements for ADR in California. Therefore, a notable legal contradiction is present, though not a direct violation of a specific statute since the scraped law snippet is not available to directly contradict the contract change, but a reasonable contradiction of legal spirit.

perturbation.original_text: 11.4 Newegg represents and warrants that it holds the necessary rights to permit Allied to use Newegg's Marks in accordance with the license granted in Section 6.1; and that to Newegg's actual knowledge the use, reproduction, distribution or transmission of Newegg's Marks will not violate any criminal laws, or any rights of any third parties, including, but not limited to, such violations as infringement or misappropriation of any copyright, patent, trademark, trade secret, music, image, or other proprietary or property right, false advertising, unfair competition, defamation, invasion of privacy or rights of celebrity, violation of any anti-discrimination law or regulation, or any other right of any person or entity.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.4 Newegg represents and warrants that it holds the necessary rights to permit Allied to use Newegg's Marks in accordance with the license granted in Section 6.1.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting the warranty that the use of Newegg's Marks will not violate any laws or third-party rights, Newegg is removing a significant assurance to Allied. This omission creates a potential contradiction with California's implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, which is part of every contract. If Newegg's Marks do infringe on someone else's rights and Allied is sued, Allied may argue that Newegg breached this implied covenant by failing to ensure that the licensed marks were legally safe to use.
perturbation.law_explanation: California Civil Code Section 1655 states that 'Stipulations which are necessary to make a contract reasonable, or conformable to usage, are implied, in respect to matters concerning which the contract manifests no contrary intention.' It is reasonable to assume that a warranty of non-infringement is necessary when licensing intellectual property. By removing the explicit warranty, Allied is left vulnerable and this omission may violate the implied covenant.
perturbation.scraped_snippet: California Code, CIV 1655 skip to content home accessibility FAQ feedback sitemap login x Quick Search: Bill Number Bill Keyword Home Bill Information California Law Publications Other Resources My Subscriptions My Favorites California Law >> >> Code Section Code Section Code: Select Code CONS BPC CIV CCP COM CORP EDC ELEC EVID FAM FIN FGC FAC GOV HNC HSC INS LAB MVC PEN PROB PCC PRC PUC RTC SHC UIC VEH WAT WIC Article: Section: Code: Select Code All BPC CIV CCP COM CORP EDC ELEC EVID FAM FIN FGC FAC GOV HNC HSC INS LAB MVC PEN PROB PCC PRC PUC RTC SHC UIC VEH WAT WIC Section: Keyword(s): Code Search Text Search Up^ << Previous Next >> cross-reference chaptered bills PDF | Add To My Favorites Search Phrase: Code Text Civil Code - CIV DIVISION 3. OBLIGATIONS [1427 - 3273.69] ( Heading of Division 3 amended by Stats. 1988, Ch. 160, Sec. 14. ) PART 2. CONTRACTS [1549 - 1701] ( Part 2 enacted 1872. ) TITLE 3. INTERPRETATION OF CONTRACTS [1635 - 1663] ( Title 3 enacted 1872. ) 1655. Stipulations which are necessary to make a contract reasonable, or conformable to usage, are implied, in respect to matters concerning which the contract manifests no contrary intention. (Enacted 1872.)
perturbation.justification: The omission of the warranty regarding the use of Newegg's Marks violating laws or third-party rights creates a potential contradiction with California Civil Code Section 1655. The original contract explicitly provided an assurance that the use of the marks would not infringe on any third-party rights or violate any laws. By removing this assurance, the modified contract becomes arguably less 'reasonable' as it pertains to intellectual property licensing. According to the scraped law snippet, 'Stipulations which are necessary to make a contract reasonable... are implied... concerning which the contract manifests no contrary intention.' While the omission doesn't explicitly contradict the law (the law implies terms rather than mandating specific clauses), the removal of a standard warranty of non-infringement in an IP licensing agreement could be interpreted as making the contract less reasonable, thus opening the door to the implication of such a warranty under California law. The level of contradiction is moderate, because the law doesn't directly state the warranty must exist, but the omission can permit a court to imply that such a warranty was required to be reasonable.
